metadata.title: A Lanthanide MOF Thin-Film Fixed with Co3O4 Nano-Anchors as a Highly Efficient Luminescent Sensor for Nitrofuran Antibiotics

sections.text:
detection of nitrofuran antibiotics (NFAs) is an important challenge. Herein, we designed a chemical sensor based on a thin-film composed of the lanthanide metal-organic framework (Ln-MOF) {[Eu2(BCA)3(H2O)(DMF)3]·0.5DMF·H2O}n (EuBCA, in which BCA is 2,2’-biquinoline-4,4’-dicarboxylate) coated on a cost-effective stainless steel wire mesh (SSWM) by Co3O4 nano-anchor fixation method. The MOF coatings were well adhered to the SSWM, resulting in a three-dimensional porous, flexible, and processable sensor. The structure of the as-prepared MOF thin-film was confirmed by powder
X-ray diffraction (PXRD), and the surface morphology was examined by scanning electron microscopy (SEM). Significantly, the Eu-BCA thin-film was highly selective and sensitive to NFAs, and yet remained unaffected by other common antibiotics that may be present. The limits of detection for nitrofurantoin (NFT) and nitrofurazone (NFZ) are 0.21 and 0.16 mm, respectively. NFAs were also successfully detected in water from the Pearl River in Guangzhou, and from bovine serum samples. Hence, the reported Ln-MOF thinfilm is a promising sensor for the detection of NFAs, thereby helping to protect human beings from all manner of hazards that arise from the abuse of antibiotics in livestock breeding.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Nitrofurans are a type of synthetic broad-spectrum antibiotic ; particular examples are nitrofurantoin (NFT) and nitrofurazone (NFZ), the structure of which consists of a 5-nitrofuran ring group. Nitrofuran antibiotics (NFAs) are effective for the treatment of protozoan and bacterial infections in human, and are also commonly employed as feed additives for poultry and swinem, as well as within aquaculture for the treatment of certain bacterial infections, such as gastrointestinal enteritis caused by Escherichia coli and Salmonella spp.[1] Despite their therapeutic value, the abuse of antibiotics brings a lot of adverse effects. NFAs have been shown to be both mutagenic and carcinogenic.[2] Constant presence of low concentrations of antibiotics, such as those found in aquatic environments, are expected to increase the rate that pathogenic bacteria develop antibiotic resistance, making these pollutants of acute concern.[3] These antibiotics have been banned in the European Union, and has also been regarded as illegal in the United States, China, and most other countries.[1] Unfortunately, residual NFAs are still found frequently in food products, surface and groundwater, as well as in drinking water; NFAs continue to be of regulatory concern. The residual NFAs can be transmitted to humans through the food chain, this would be harmful to human health.[4] Therefore, it is crucial to establish a highly sensitive analytical method to accurately and effectively determine the presence of NFAs. At present, various detection techniques, such as GC–MS, LC–MS, and micellar electrokinetic capillary chromatography (EC) have been reported.[5] Aside from these methods, fluorescence signaling has become an efficient and important in-field technique, with excellent operability, short response time, and high sensitivity; it is therefore popular for this application.[6]
Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with large surface areas, adjustable pore size, and diverse skeletal structures are created from a supramolecular assembly of metal ions or clusters with organic ligands. They have shown potential for applications in many fields, such as gas storage, drug delivery, nanoscale reactors, proton conduction, and many more.[7] Recently, a novel class of materials, Ln-MOFs, have been utilized for chemical detection. Their suitability for this application is due to their excellent luminescent behavior with a long lifetime, high color purity, and intense sharp emissions in the near-infrared and visible regions.[8] However, it should be pointed out that most published work regarding Ln-MOFs as luminescent sensors were performed using the materials in the form of loose powders.[9] Making MOFs powders into dispersions is a time-consuming process, and does not sufficiently separate the powder from the analyte solution for recycling. Additionally, the disposal of these pulverous materials leads to resource consumption and environmental pollution. In contrast, luminescent MOF thin-films and membranes have distinct advantages over solution-based sensors, such as good stability and portability, tunable shape and size, non-contamination to the target systems, real-time detection, extensive suitability for gas/vapor sensing, and recycling.[10] However, work relating to the detection of NFAs using Ln-MOF thin-films, even in the form of powders, have not yet been reported. In our previous work,[6a, 11] flurorine or indium-doped tin oxide (FTO/ITO) conductive glasses were selected as the substrates, which always produced a 2D surface for the fabrication of MOF thin-films sensors. As a result, only 2D-MOF porous coatings were available for contact with the analytes. Moreover, the brittle nature of FTO/ITO glasses means that the fabricated thin-films cannot be re-used. In order to overcome these problems, a porous and easily processable 3D substrate is thus required. However, since the rigid MOFs crystals are incompatible with the solid substrate, it is still a challenge to enhance the interface adhesion between the MOF thin-films and the smooth substrate. We were inspired by afforestation — an effective strategy to conserve soil and water, and prevent erosion. Herein, we tried to mimic this method by planting Co3O4 nanowire arrays [a] F. Zhang, H. (“trees”) on cost-effective stainless-steel wire mesh (SSWM), to act as anchors in order to stabilize the MOF (“soil”) coatings, thereby constructing a macroscopic 3D flexible porous and processable MOF sensor. In addition, considering the electrondeficient nature of the NFAs, with electron-withdrawing nitro groups on the furan ring, we selected a p-conjugated ligand, 2,2’-biquinoline-4,4’-dicarboxylate, to construct MOF thin-films of {[Eu2(BCA)3(H2O)(DMF)3]·0.5DMF·H2O}n (Eu-BCA, in which BCA is 2,2’-biquinoline-4,4’-dicarboxylate) with electron-rich free nitrogen atoms. As expected, the Eu-BCA thin-films exhibited characteristics of Eu3 + red emission, and showed both high sensitivity and selectivity for the luminescent sensing of NFAs (NFZ and NFT were the representative NFA analytes) in aqueous media, even in the presence of other interfering antibiotics. The limits of detection of NFZ and NFT were 0.21 and 0.16 mm, respectively. Additionally, this thin-film sensor can sense NFAs not only in deionized water, but also in real samples (original water from Pearl River and bovine serum samples), and can be reused in a consecutive testing process. This Eu-BCA thin-film provides a platform for rapid and convenient detection of nitrofuran antibiotics.

sections.heading: Results and Discussion
sections.text:
Optimization of Eu-BCA thin-film fabrication
The detailed fabrication process of the Eu-BCA thin-film is illustrated in Scheme 1. When the bare SSWM (Figure 1 a) was directly inserted into the MOF precursor solution, a large amount of white flocks were discovered at the bottom of the autoclaves, instead of forming a film on the SSWM. Therefore, synthesis of the Co3O4 nanowire arrays on the SSWM is a key step (Figure 1 b). These Co3O4 motifs can be used not only as the anchors but also as nucleation centers, by fixing the MOF crystal on every stainless steel wire firmly. Furthermore, to investigate the effect of the concentration of MOF precursor solution on the resulting thin-films, MOF films were prepared with different concentrations of the precursor solution (concentrations of ligand and Eu3 + are equal) of 0.005 m, 0.01 m, 0.015 m, and 0.02 m. As shown in Figure 1 c and d, when the thin-film was fabricated using relatively low concentrations of precursor solution (0.005 m and 0.01 m), only some scattered
MOF crystal blocks piled up on the modified SSWM. In contrast, with higher concentrations of 0.015 m and 0.02 m, a continuous and compact Eu-BCA thin-film was formed on the substrate (Figure 1 e and f). It is worth noting that the higher the concentration of precursor solution, the more MOF flocks were produced at the bottom of the autoclaves, thus the concentration of 0.015 m was selected as optimum for subsequent synthetic experiment.

sections.heading: Characterization of the Eu-BCA thin-film
sections.text:
SEM images of the Eu-BCA thin-film formed on the SSWM substrate coated with the Co3O4 nano-anchors are shown in Figure 2 a and b. These images display that the MOF blocks are compact, and adhere well to the surface of the substrate. Figure 2 c is representative of the area of the interface between the MOF film and the nano-anchor, this shows that the nanoanchors penetrate into the formed MOF crystal plates, making the thin film firmly anchored on the substrate. The cross-section image (Figure 2 d) shows that thickness of the film is about 6 mm, and the MOF crystals and Co3O4 nano-anchors are intertwined. The elemental distribution and composition of the

films determined by energy dispersive X-ray (EDX)-mapping is shown in Figure S1. The experimental PXRD pattern of the synthesized Eu-BCA powder sample that was collected at the bottom of autoclave was in agreement with the simulated pattern,[12] but some peak positions of the thin-film are slightly different (Figure S2). This may be due to the fact that the Co3O4 nanowire arrays act as nucleation centers, thereby inducing the preferential growth of crystal faces that are different from the directly generated powder samples; or due to macroscopic lattice distortion caused by residual stress.
Luminescence properties and processibility of the Eu-BCA thin-film
The excitation and emission spectra of the Eu-BCA thin-films were recorded at room temperature in deionized water. As shown in Figure 3, the excitation spectrum shows a broad band in the range of 250–390 nm, which is ascribed to the
p–p* electron transition of the organic ligands, and the peak maximum in the excitation spectrum is at 358 nm. As expected, when excited at 358 nm, the emission spectrum of the thin-film exhibits the characteristic emission of Eu3 + . The emission bands centred at 591, 615, 650, and 697 nm can be attributed to 5D0!7FJ (J = 1, 2, 3, 4) transitions of Eu3 + , respectively. The most prominent characteristic emission peak of the thinfilm is presented at 615 nm, which is a typical electric dipole transition, and is very sensitive to the local symmetry of Eu3+ . Additionally, the optical images depicted in Figure S3 show flexible properties of the thin-film: bendability and rollability. Moreover, this film can be readily processed into various sizes and shapes, as shown in the inset of Figure 3, rectangle, circle, square, triangle, and trapezoid shapes were observed as bright red light by the naked eye under UV-light irradiation of 365 nm, which suggests the possibility of the thin-film acting as a novel luminescence or sensor device under different topology requirements.

sections.heading: Sensing Properties of the Eu-BCA thin-film
sections.text:
The selective detection of antibiotics in water is highly desirable for practical applications. To explore the ability of the EuBCA thin-film to sense a trace quantity of antibiotics in aqueous solution, the stability of the thin-film in water was firstly investigated using time-dependent luminescence intensity analysis of the strongest 5D0!7F2 emission at 615 nm. As illustrated in Figure S4, more than 95 % of the original peak intensity was retained within the first two minutes, and over 90 % remained after an hour. What’s more, extending the time to one week, the emission remained at about 90 % of its original intensity, and PXRD of the recovered film was almost the same as the fresh film (Figures S5 and S6). All the results indicate that this film is water stable, and meets the requirements of the test in water. Subsequently, five classes of frequently used antibiotics,[13] nitrofurans (nitrofurazone, NFZ and nitrofurantoin, NFT), nitroimidazoles (metronidazole, MDZ and dimetridazole, DTZ), sulfonamides (sulfadiazine, SDZ and sulfamethazine, SMZ), chloramphenicols (chloramphenicol, CAP and thiamphenicol, THI), and b-lactams (penicillin, PCL) were investigated. The asfabricated films were directly immersed in a 0.5 mm aqueous solution of these antibiotics. The luminescence sensing properties were recorded and compared in Figure 4. The results
reveal that different kinds of antibiotics display markedly different quenching effects on the luminescence of the Eu-BCA thinfilm. Compared with other classes of antibiotics, the nitroimidazoles (MDZ, DTZ) had a slight quenching effect on the film. Significantly, the addition of the same amount of NFAs (NFT, NFZ) almost completely quenched the emission of the film, demonstrating the high selectivity of this film sensor toward NFAs. The clear quenching that was induced by nitrogroup containing antibiotics could be due to electron transfer from the electron-donating ligands of the Eu-BCA MOF to the electron-deficient antibiotic molecules.
To further prove that the NFAs induce fluorescence quenching, concentration-dependent studies were carried out on the luminescence properties of the Eu-BCA thin-film in the presence of NFAs. It was observed that the fluorescence intensity of the films progressively decreases upon incremental addition of NFZ and NFT (Figure 5 a and c). As a result, when the concentration of NFZ or NFT was increased to 0.6 mm, the fluores-

cence intensity was almost totally quenched. Moreover, the optical images of the Eu-BCA thin-film immersed in water before and after addition of 0.1 mm of NFZ or NFT had distinct luminescence color changes (inset of Figure 5 a and c), suggesting that the as-prepared films can potentially function as an unaided eye-based portable sensor. In general, the quenching efficiency could be quantitatively explained using the Stern– Volmer (S–V) equation:[14] I0/I = KSV[A] + 1, where I0 and I are the fluorescence intensities in the absence and presence of the analyte, respectively, [A] is the molar concentration of the analyte, and KSV is the quenching constant (m
@1). As shown in Figure 5 b and d, a good linear relationship between the analytical signal of I0/I and the NFZ/NFT concentration was observed from 0 to 600 mm, indicating that the dynamic or static quenching processes.[14] The Ksv value is calculated as 2.2 V 104 m@1 for NFZ and 1.6 V 104 m@1 for NFT, revealing a strong quenching effect on the Eu-BCA thin-film luminescence. Moreover, there is a good linear relationship between the fluorescence intensity and NFA concentration range from 0 to 40 mm (Figures S7 and S8), and the limits of detection for NFZ and NFT are estimated to be 0.21 and 0.16 mm, respectively, based on the three-sigma rule.[15] In addition, considering nitroimidazoles (MDZ, DTZ) had a certain quenching effect on the film, the analogous studies were also implemented (Figures S9– S12). The Ksv value was calculated as 9.9 V 10 2 for MDZ and 1.2 V 103 for DTZ, which are far less than those of the NFAs, further demonstrating the Eu-BCA thin-film has a high selectivity toward NFAs.
Anti-interference is one of the essential conditions for chemical sensors. Hence, we investigated the fluorescence response of the Eu-BCA thin-film towards other potential interfering antibiotics. All samples were tested under identical conditions to the fluorescent response studies illustrated in Figure 6. Remarkably, even if the concentration of the interfering groups is twice that of the NFAs, slight or negligible fluorescence change is observed. Upon introducing NFAs (NFZ, NFT) into the mixture of the films and other antibiotics, the fluorescence was significantly quenched, which confirms the high selectivity of the Eu-BCA thin film for detection of NFAs, even in the presence of a higher concentration of other antibiotics. Considering that NFAs contain nitro groups, in order to better evaluate the specificity of the thin-film to NFAs, the luminescence response in the presence of other interference nitro compounds, such as nitrobenzene (NB), 4-nitrotoluene (NT), 2,4-dinitrotoluene (DNT), 1,3-dinitrobenzene (DNB), and 2,4,6-trinitrotoluene (TNT) were also investigated. As depicted in Figure S13, the quenching of the fluorescence intensity of NFAs (0.5 mm) remains almost the same in the presence of nitro compounds (1.0 mm). These results clearly highlight the good sensitivity and selectivity of the Eu-BCA thin-film towards NFAs. Additionally, we also applied this thin-film luminescence sensor in real water samples. In this section, different concentrations of PA solutions were prepared with natural water specimens collected from the Pearl River near our school of Sun Yat-sen University. As shown in Figures S14 and S15, the quenching is mostly similar in nature. The KSV values are calculated to be 1.9 V

Detection of NFAs in bovine serum
It has been found that NFAs were commonly employed as feed-additives for livestock (poultry, swine, and cattle), which would potentially bring harmful effects on human health. Thus, the determination of NFAs in domestic animals is urgently needed. Herein, we applied the film sensor for the detection of NFZ in bovine serum samples. The samples were spiked with certain amounts of a NFZ standard solution, and the results are shown in Table 1. From Table 1, it was found that the recovery of NFZ is in the range of 91.2 %–103 %, and the relative standard deviation (RSD) was less than 6.0 %. These results suggest that the proposed method has potential application in the assessment of food safety.

sections.heading: Recyclability of the Eu-BCA thin-film
sections.text:
Compared to the luminescent sensors based on suspension or solution, thin-films have intrinsic advantages for regeneration. As for the solution-based sensors, recycling the fluorescentactive substances from homogeneous solution is very difficult. For a suspension, the tedious procedure of centrifuging is always necessary. Conversely, films can be easily recycled by taking them out of the analyte solution directly and washing with an appropriate solvent. As well as the water stability we discussed above, in this case, the stability of the Eu-BCA thin-
films in different aqueous solutions of antibiotics is of equal importance for reusability. Thus, the PXRDs of the thin-films after being immersed in different antibiotic solutions were firstly investigated. Figure S18 shows that the PXRDs of the recovered thin-films are almost identical and hardly changed compared to the original spectrum, illustrating that the thinfilms are stable both in water and in aqueous solutions of antibiotics. The intrinsic stability provides the essential conditions for recycling. The regeneration of the Eu-BCA thin-film was tested by monitoring the fluorescence signal of the film in a 0.5 mm aqueous NFZ solution and a blank solution after rinsing with water. As shown in Figure 7, the fluorescence intensity and quenching ability of the Eu-BCA thin-film were essentially retained after using the film for five cycles. These results suggest that the Eu-BCA thin-film meets the high standard of realtime detection and recycling.

sections.heading: Mechanism of luminescence quenching
sections.text:
To understand the origin of the high selectivity of the Eu-BCA thin-film towards NFAs, the mechanism of quenching was investigated. Generally, fluorescence quenching by electrontransfer from the conduction band (CB) of the MOF to the LUMO of the electron-deficient nitro analyte is a well-established quenching mechanism, due to the higher energy of the MOF conduction band compared to the LUMOs of the ana-

lytes.[16] The different band gap between the CB of the MOF and the LUMOs of the analytes may result in various driving forces for electron-transfer. As shown in Table S1, LUMO energies are in good agreement with the maximum quenching efficiency (NFAs @ nitroimidazoles @ other antibiotics) observed for NFAs. It is noteworthy that CAP and NFAs have nearly equal LUMO energies, but their quenching efficiencies are quite different, suggesting that electron-transfer is not the sole mechanism for the observed luminescence quenching.
Another reason for the quenching might be the inner-filter effect (IFE), which results from the absorption of the excitation and emission lights of the fluorescent substance or both simultaneously by other absorbents in the detection system.[17] The greater the spectral overlap between the absorbance spectrum of the analytes and the excitation spectrum of the sensors, the higher IFE will be produced. As shown in the UV/Vis absorption spectra of Figure 8, the absorption band of NFAs and nitroimidazoles have the greatest degree of overlapping with the excitation spectrum of the Eu-BCA thin-film, thus suggesting that the quenching effect of NFAs and nitroimidazoles in the fluorescence emission spectrum is larger than other antibiotics. As a result, the coexistence of electron-transfer and inner-filter effect makes NFAs show a higher luminescence quenching effect compared with the other tested analytes.

sections.heading: Conclusion
sections.text:
In summary, taking advantage of Ln-MOF and thin-film properties, a novel flexible and processable Eu-BCA thin-film has been fabricated through a nano-anchor fixation method, and has for the first time been exploited as an efficient sensor for the detection of nitrofuran antibiotics. This film sensor provides a 3D surface for contact with analytes, and exhibited high selectivity and sensitivity towards NFAs. Significantly, this thin-film can be considered as a universal luminescent sensor for detecting NFAs in real samples, and can also be recycled. The synergistic effect of electron-transfer and the inner-filter effect results in an excellent luminescent quenching performance for NFAs. It is believed that this valid sensor device possesses the potential to serve as a powerful diagnostic tool for NFA- contaminated water and food, and prevents human
beings from being damaged by the abuse of antibiotics in livestock breeding.

sections.heading: Materials and methods
sections.text: All reagents were of analytical grade, purchased from commercial sources and used directly without further purification. Powder Xray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were performed on a D/MAX 2200VPC diffractometer with Cu Ka radiation (l= 1.5406 a) at a voltage of 40 kV and a current of 26 mA cm@2. The morphologies, microstructures, and compositions of the film were characterized by an ultra-high resolution field-emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM, SU8010, Hitachi). All the emission spectra were recorded using a Shimadzu RF-5301 PC spectrofluorophotometer from 500 to 750 nm, with the excitation wavelength fixed at 358 nm. The absorption spectra were recorded on a Shimadzu UV/ Vis-NIR Spectrophotometer.

sections.heading: Synthesis of the Co3O4 nano-anchor-coated SSWM
sections.text: Firstly, one segment of SSWM (2.5 cm V 10 cm) was carefully cleaned with HCl solution (1.0 m) in an ultrasound bath for 10 min to remove any possible oxide layer from the surface, and then rinsed with deionized water and absolute ethanol several times. Secondly, Co(NO3)2·6 H2O (1.45 g, 5 mmol), urea (3.0 g, 50 mmol), and NH4F (0.19 g, 5 mmol) were dissolved in deionized water (50 mL) to form a homogeneous magenta solution. The above-prepared solution (20 mL) was transferred into a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, and the pre-treated SSWM substrates were rolled and then inserted vertically into the autoclaves, which was sealed and maintained at 120 8C for 6 h. After being cooled down to room temperature, the precursor samples were collected and washed with deionized water and absolute ethanol several times to remove the unreacted reactants and free debris, then dried at 60 8C for 2 h. Finally, the products were calcined at 350 8C for 3 h in air to transform the precursor into Co3O4 nanowire.

sections.heading: Preparation of the Eu-BCA MOF thin-film
sections.text: The Eu-BCA thin film was fabricated by solvothermal synthesis. (116.8 mg, 0.3 mmol) of 2,2’-biquinoline-4,4-dicarboxylic acid disodium salt (Na2BCA) was dispersed in N,N-dimethylformamide (20 mL), a few drops of hydrochloric acid (0.5 m) were added to acquire a clear solution. Then, Eu(NO3)3·6 H2O (133.8 mg, 0.3 mmol) was added to the above solution and stirred well. The Co3O4 nanowire-coated SSWM was inserted vertically into the autoclave. The reactant solution was then poured into the autoclave and left in an oven at 80 8C for 3 days. The autoclave was allowed to naturally cool down to room temperature. The thin-film was thoroughly washed with deionized water and ethanol several times to remove free debris, then dried at 60 8C for 2 h.

sections.heading: Luminescent sensing experiments
sections.text:
The as-prepared thin-film on rolled SSWM substrate was cut into a suitable size for the fluorescence cuvette. Then, the post-processed thin-films were directly immersed into a solution of different antibiotics of various concentrations. The luminescence data were collected under excitation at 358 nm at room temperature.

Preparation of Real water samples
The real water sample was collected from the Pearl River (the biggest river in South China).The collected water sample was filtered through a 0.45 mm pore size membrane to remove suspended particles, and then NFAs were added in a series of concentrations.

sections.heading: Preparation of serum samples
sections.text: NFAs of various different concentrations were added to the bovine serum samples separately to prepare the spiked samples. The bovine serum was diluted 100 times by Tris-HCl buffer (pH 7.4). The results from three individual experiments were averaged.

metadata.abstractText: Nitrofurans are a group of widely used veterinary antibiotics, which have been banned due to antibiotics pollution. Development of a rapid and effective method for the detection of nitrofuran antibiotics (NFAs) is an important challenge. Herein, we designed a chemical sensor based on a thin-film composed of the lanthanide metal-organic framework (Ln-MOF) {[Eu2(BCA)3(H2O)(DMF)3]·0.5DMF·H2O}n (EuBCA, in which BCA is 2,2’-biquinoline-4,4’-dicarboxylate) coated on a cost-effective stainless steel wire mesh (SSWM) by Co3O4 nano-anchor fixation method. The MOF coatings were well adhered to the SSWM, resulting in a three-dimensional porous, flexible, and processable sensor. The structure of the as-prepared MOF thin-film was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), and the surface morphology was examined by scanning electron microscopy (SEM). Significantly, the Eu-BCA thin-film was highly selective and sensitive to NFAs, and yet remained unaffected by other common antibiotics that may be present. The limits of detection for nitrofurantoin (NFT) and nitrofurazone (NFZ) are 0.21 and 0.16 mm, respectively. NFAs were also successfully detected in water from the Pearl River in Guangzhou, and from bovine serum samples. Hence, the reported Ln-MOF thinfilm is a promising sensor for the detection of NFAs, thereby helping to protect human beings from all manner of hazards that arise from the abuse of antibiotics in livestock breeding.
